ygData.msgSnippet: You can still use HyperNEAT to tackle this problem.  Basically, take what variables make up a protein and use those as your geometry.  For example, if what

You can still use HyperNEAT to tackle this problem.  Basically, take what v=
ariables make up a protein and use those as your geometry.  For example, if=
 what distinguishes two proteins are their size and number of connections, =
then those variables become your x and y axes and every protein is a point =
in that space.  If you have more than 3 variables, you can still use HyperN=
EAT to create N-dimensional substrates, although the cost of creating the n=
etwork increases.

Jason G.

l@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken,
> 
> In my problem, the nodes do not have co-ordi=
nates. They represent  individual 
> proteins. I've data about interaction =
between a given pair of  proteins i.e 
> whether they interact or not. The =
number of proteins is  fixed ( around 3000) . 
> But, the interaction set i=
s incomplete. With the  limited information I've as 
> training data,I want=
 to calculate the  probability of interactions for a given 
> pair of prote=
ins. 
> 
> 
> It's true that the result depends on the similarities of grap=
h  geometry between 
> the training and test data. My hypothesis is that I =
can  make use of the number 
> of interacting partners and interaction  pro=
pensities to explore unknown 
> interactions.
> 
> Thanks,
> Mridul
> 
>

> Mridul,
> 
> One thing t=
o consider here is that if your nodes can be given coordinates, then 
> you=
r problem looks like a CPPN:  You are basically asking for (x1,y1,x2,y2) 
>=
 whether the two coordinates are connected.  That's essentially what a CPPN=
 does.  
> So if you tried to train a CPPN to answer correctly for your par=
ticular graph, 
> then you'd be getting a CPPN encoding of that graph.  The=
 part I am a little 
> fuzzy about is how that would help with a different =
such graph.  To the extent 
> the two graphs overlap, it would work, but if=
 they don't, I'm not sure how 
> learning from the first graph would genera=
lize to the second.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Mridul P <p_=
mridul@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Ken,
> > 
> > The testing data is related to the=
 same graph. I believe that there is some 
> > underlying geometry between =
the nodes in the graph, and there should be some 
> > regularities in the c=
onnectivity. Other researchers have applied HMMs, Naive 
> > Bayes classifi=
ers etc to solve this problem with limited results.
> > 
> > Thanks for the=
 heads up.

> > Mridul, whe=
re does the testing data (i.e. what you will test it on after 
> > training=
 is over) come from?  Is it from a different graph or the same graph? 
> > =
The reason I ask is that it probably matters whether the nodes will be the =
same 
> >
> > nodes (i.e. because they are from the same graph) or nodes fr=
om an entirely 
> > different graph.
> > 
> > In general, it does sound lik=
e you could create an array of 9000 inputs and 
> > highlight the ones that=
 you are asking about.  The main question for HyperNEAT 
> 
> > is whether =
those 9000 inputs can be situated in a meaningful geometry?  For 
> > examp=
le, is it naturally 300x300?  Or maybe something else?  If there is a 
> > =
geometry to them, and if there are regularities in their connectivity, then=
 in 
> 
> > principle HyperNEAT might be a good choice for learning that pa=
ttern.
> > 
> > Also, note that with 9000 inputs, there will generally be a=
 computational cost 
> 
> > to activating the network.
> > 
> > ken
> >

aph with a large number of nodes (~9000), and about 3000 edges

 >

ny 2
